title: Lebesgue's density theorem
summary: In mathematics, Lebesgue's density theorem states that for any Lebesgue measurable set A âŠ‚ R n {\displaystyle A\subset \mathbb {R} ^{n}} , the "density" of A is 0 or 1 at almost every point in R n {\displaystyle \mathbb {R} ^{n}} . Additionally, the "density" of A is 1 at almost every point in A.   Intuitively, this means that the "edge" of A, the set of points in A whose "neighborhood" is partially in A and partially outside of A, is negligible.
